subject: Art
title: Romanticism
description: Emotion, nature, and the sublime â€” art rebels against reason.

hook.text: A lone figure stands atop a mountain, gazing into swirling fog. Caspar David Friedrich's 'Wanderer Above the Sea of Fog' captures Romanticism perfectly: emotion, nature, the individual, and the overwhelming sublime.

buildup.text: Romanticism (1780-1850) was a reaction against the Age of Reason and industrialization. Artists championed: emotion over logic, nature over civilization, individual experience over universal rules, and the sublime over the beautiful.

discovery.text: The sublime: a feeling of awe mixed with terror â€” standing before a massive waterfall, a violent storm, an infinite sea. Romantic painters sought to capture experiences that overwhelmed rational understanding.

twist.text: Delacroix's 'Liberty Leading the People' combined Romanticism with politics â€” a passionate, idealized scene of revolution. Art could be emotionally stirring AND politically revolutionary. Beauty as a weapon.

climax.text: Turner's late seascapes dissolved form into pure light and color â€” ships becoming ghosts in golden mist. Critics mocked them. Today we see them as proto-Impressionism, decades ahead of their time.

punchline.text: Romanticism said: feel first, think later. Art should stir your soul, not just please your eyes.

quiz.question: What was Romanticism a reaction against?
options: The Age of Reason and industrialization
